Last night in class, we discussed that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement" and the second, "displacement." Casey distinguishes that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force: we're running out of time, we've saved time, we're just in time. He argues that using place as the center of culture fosters a more grounded community. (Please note that this is a rough summary, and I offer this disclaimer in case my professor or classmates happen to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly resonated with me.

GOP gets scolded on recruitment; naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy. The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville seemed to proceed as usual, with nearly 200 people leaving as new Americans. Just before the new citizens departed the June 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in ceremony encouraged them to visit a voter registration table – a common sight at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: the individuals distributing forms were Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box had been pre-checked to make all new voters members of the GOP. This raised suspicions for Linda Cross, who attended to watch her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

The game features fluid movement, is bug and crash-free, and offers a wealth of story content and options for each day, including multiple practices, events, and games. This review is based solely on my experience with MyCareer, and so far, it's 10/10. The Facescan feature worked well for me, although the first attempt resulted in an unusual forehead shape. Notably, using the MyNBA2K17 app allows for free Facescan and daily VC earnings. #sellout

Magic fans beware... Wizards seems hesitant to create a decent digital game. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social experience meant to be enjoyed with friends (or frenemies), filled with laughter, trash talk, and game-winning moments. Wizards of the Coast appears to have forgotten this. When playing with friends, you're unable to earn gold, which is crucial. Gold is so vital that a daily cap has been implemented, considering it unlocks everything in-game. However, be prepared for a lengthy and monotonous 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, with whom you can't even communicate. If you choose to play for free, it will take approximately 4 hours a day for over a month, solo, to unlock the cards.

Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy, I'll address the drawbacks first. I generally dislike prequels, as they technically move the story backward rather than forward, which is an issue inherent to every prequel. However, they often provide additional story depth. The combat feels somewhat unrefined and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City achieved. As of this writing (26/10/2013), a game-breaking bug prevents the completion of a side mission, although the main storyline remains unaffected. Some gadgets are assigned to inconvenient hotkeys, requiring excessive keyboard navigation, which can disrupt combos during combat.

They basically fixed Shadow Warrior (2013), i.e. The boss fights are awesome, and the weapons feel very nice (maybe not as good as D44M's, but still solid). Enemies aren't too spongy if you're not too careless with handling elemental and upgrade aspects. The upgrade system is really balanced, and once you get the hang of it, it's not too tedious. The elemental mechanics and limited ammo gently encourage you to use different weapons. There are many cool, unique (a key distinction from Borderlands' 'rng' formula) weapons that remain viable throughout most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's contributions.

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics on all fronts, including ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, and more. I felt a stronger connection to this character as well. Although the story starts off rough, it significantly improves as you progress, a trend I've noticed in every AC game. Edward was an intriguing character, and the side characters were equally captivating. I found that the collectibles in this game held more significance than in previous ones, possibly due to their greater purpose in the game. While not required, they were enjoyable to obtain and rewarded in a balanced manner, making them feel worthwhile.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, provided you have the means to purchase gun parts, which is my primary concern: it's pay-to-win. If I could overlook this, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and the HRV is an excellent concept. I'd prefer this game over any Call of Duty title, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you're comfortable with this model, then by all means, have fun. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, it's best to let this one pass; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death can be frustrating at times. I'm on my first playthrough and lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. A reload option at that point would have been appreciated. I've since used a 3rd party mod/save tool to avoid such failures. Additionally, the aiming reticule is somewhat small and the zoom feature underpowered. Despite these issues, it's been a blast. I'm not typically a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up elements is great. I've been playing it as often as I can, always thinking 'just one more mission, just one more supply run' - or I'm eager to get to safety before shutting the game down.

An absolute great strategy game. Having played every single other wargame, including European Escalation and ALB, I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is impressive. Although I'm not sure of the exact count, there's a vast array. The graphics are stunning, the sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is surprisingly entertaining, and I'm not kidding. However, if anyone thinks this game is 'easy', or if you're new to the strategy genre, it may take some time to master. Don't get upset, you will lose units. Just plan ahead, always have anti-air and anti-tank defenses in place.

I was initially biased against this game before playing it, and I wasn't even sure about purchasing it. The portal gun and portal concept seemed unusual to me, despite my fondness for science fiction. However, I was pleasantly surprised. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal - just amazing. While it can be cheesy at times, the humor is generally well-executed. Each story character has their own unique sense of humor, and their distinct personalities shine through. The level design is also impressive. Notably, I never played the first Portal game, but I plan to do so if I can spare the time. Playing the sequel was what ultimately led me to consider playing the original.

Let's start with the pros and cons, followed by my thoughts on this game. + Some of the best characters + Good story + Loads of content + Customizable character (you can choose to be male or female, or whatever you like) + You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest) - Bad graphics (although I don't think graphics really matter) - Weird and awkward love scenes - Invisible walls - One mission, in my opinion, was boring, but everyone has different tastes - This isn't necessarily bad or good, but for those who care, your protagonist can't talk. Now, for my thoughts. I love this game. It's probably one of the best RPGs or games in general that I've ever played. So, if you're an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet in the UK, just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others return, and are instantly recognisable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is also present. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect and very faithful to Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are extremely well executed. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, and is seamlessly woven into combos, making it quite distinct from High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another key distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies, such as Seekers, require a switch to a ranged blaster.

4k+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo Excellent port and a great entry point if new to the series. Just keep in mind there's lots of skippable dialogue. As usual, I'd suggest using a gamepad, but personally, I had no issues with a keyboard/mouse setup, both completely rebindable. The price is about right, and I wouldn't have been unhappy with a purchase. More than half the DLC is included for free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended game to all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between action sequences. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues at release, and after numerous patches, the game runs smoothly. In my opinion, this is a great and enjoyable game, despite the format being somewhat frustrating (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies upon story progression). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play as Batman and an additional character), and the ability to use the controller for most segments of the game, but the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments, was greatly appreciated. Driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing APC commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you master the use of brakes to skid around corners (and when you do, navigating the city becomes really enjoyable).

Damn fine aaa fps shooter - that's the bottom line. It's visually stunning, sounds great, and plays exceptionally well - great fps mechanics, a nice story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a fantastic soundtrack. Not for the faint hearted though - some cutscenes were pretty darn cruel and vivid. But when a game overall is so great, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as I saw 'em: - no sli support - what a disappointment; I had to put the game away until I upgraded my card, as it ran poorly on my old dual gpu gtx 590. Ensure you have a fairly decent single gpu card. - some small obstacles are often unclimbable, which seems illogical.

English is not my native language, as I am Dutch. Please disregard any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into several categories: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, and replayability. 

Graphics: The game features a comic-like style. The graphics are very slick, with no unnecessary details and nice color schemes. This aesthetic works perfectly for the game. The graphics can be set to 'high' without putting excessive strain on your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor, with an Nvidia GeForce 710m card and 8GB of memory, and it runs smoothly (Windows 8.1).

Controls: The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, but also with an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I've invested in this game that I thoroughly enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from the Call of Duty series would be. However, don't buy this game thinking it's similar to Call of Duty, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. I've lost count of how many times I hear new players express frustration and complain about getting killed quickly. Oh, the shock of getting shot in the face and dying - it's not like that doesn't happen in real life. Edit: Having played this game for a while now, I've spent a considerable amount of money on it. It's one of the best multiplayer games around, a great alternative to play when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm 2 hours in and thoroughly enjoying this game. It's hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, the story and world have piqued my interest, and the puzzles are entertaining. However, the standout aspect of this game is its comedic genius. If you've played any RPG since the genre's inception, you'll appreciate the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you're new to RPGs, the humor still makes it enjoyable. If you've played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you owe it to yourself to play this game - without giving too much away, I had to pause after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. It's been a delight so far.

I'm really sorry, I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I didn't enjoy this game. The description seemed appealing, but the execution fell short. As a fan of puzzle and exploration games, I found this game to be completely unintuitive. Despite looking up how to progress, I still didn't find the gameplay enjoyable. The lack of a pause button is also concerning, especially given the timed sequences. If a pause button exists, I couldn't find it. I feel that the game is overly reliant on cut scenes, leaving me with too much downtime. I often found myself waiting, drumming my fingers, rather than engaging with the game itself.

This game... Phew, where to even start. It was absolutely breathtaking, from the story to the graphics, I was hooked. The story wasn't just any story, but actually felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the narrative my character was telling. Gameplay was great, and I learned a lot about myself through this game, mainly my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns. My gut churned the whole time, but I kept going for Uncle Fred. If you guys made a DLC or a second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this, you created an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to achieve a specific goal or 'victory'. Unlike previous games, which followed the Earth's timeline through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age, this game takes place in the future, where you're on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that 2K took a new approach and added innovative mechanics, such as the affinity system and orbital layer. However, I found that these new mechanics could be overwhelming at times. One potential improvement could be incorporating new artwork, such as the environment experienced when communicating with another leader, to further enhance the game. Overall, the game offers a fresh take on the series, but may benefit from some refinements to balance its complexity.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience. Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games. It's designed like a survival horror, where you must conserve ammo, heal your own wounds when bleeding out, and take medication when infected. The zombies feel natural and are well-animated for a free-to-play game. I highly recommend playing with 1 or 2 friends, but the community is super friendly, and you can easily make friends or chat with others via voice comms or in-game chat.

02/07/2014 - it's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game, as from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have the following two major issues. No Australian servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. I played through the offline training mode, and it was stuttering and lagging as well, which is puzzling. This, combined with the poor ping, ruins the game. Everything is plagued by artifacts - menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never experienced this before with my graphics card, so I suspected it might not like my overclock. I set my GPU back to stock, but it didn't make a difference.

Very late last night, I finished this. Although the story isn't particularly deep or interesting, the storytelling is what sets it apart. The atmosphere is richly detailed and the numerous collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I gained a lot of insight into the world of Batman, so it was somewhat disappointing that there were so few bosses in the game. However, there are plenty of future games to address this issue. The combat offers the right amount of challenge, but it's slightly on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying, as it's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable places creates a nice sense of progression, and it's the storytelling that truly makes this game stand out.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for 'To the Moon'! Never before have I felt so emotionally drained yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls can be a bit finicky and the gameplay isn't the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I didn't care one bit. Plus, the humor is great as well and it seamlessly complements the distinguished nature of the story... And the 'Doctor Who' references are endless and delightful.

Bastion is a bloody brilliant game, with a really great storyline. Set after a calamity has occurred, you begin to rebuild on the bastion. There's quite a lot of choice in the game, with options to build structures that give you an advantage, select weapons, and choose power-ups to enhance them, as well as consume drinks that provide bonus effects. The art style and music in the game are fantastic, with vibrant visuals that defy the typical dullness associated with apocalyptic settings. Best of all, the game features dynamic narration that responds to the player's actions. So, if you pick up a weapon and then switch to another in the armoury, the narration will acknowledge your new choice, saying something about taking the new weapon along.

I had originally purchased this game in its early development stages, when the only currency was spacebux and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was enjoyable. All guns were equally overpowered at this point, eliminating any imbalance issues; everyone could kill each other at any time. The game also provided unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. Given the game's claim of having 'bajillions of guns', it's surprising that they only offer 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before requiring a purchase for more. At one point, I had accumulated about 3 pages worth of guns and was brainstorming new ideas, as that's where I found the game to be most enjoyable.

This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews accurately reflect the fun of this neat little game. It's an odd yet stylish mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface are oddly charming. As a result, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper created from a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counter-attack. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it's certainly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DmC serves as the perfect entry point for newcomers to jump into the series. It showcases the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and chronicles his transformation from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he's introduced into the corrupt world he had willfully chosen to ignore, now forced to confront it.

Where do I start with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is absolutely charming, with an impressive amount of detail and a delightful mix of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It strikes a perfect balance between seriousness and humor. The character design is exceptional, featuring diverse characters with unique personalities and secrets. What sets it apart from other RPGs is the absence of violence, a refreshing concept in the genre. Drawing inspiration from Earthbound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, it's clear that this game is something special. The soundtrack is also noteworthy, easily the best I've heard in a long time.

I am recommending this solely because it's free, and might be a more 'enjoyable' experience for others. As for my experience, the 'game' had little impact on me. Half the story relies heavily on shock value. I was neither shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simplistic to elicit a reaction from me. As for the other half of the game, it attempts to portray a person's mental decline through a visual representation. It explores themes of obsession, hallucination, depression, and a few other topics. In theory, it's an intriguing concept. However, the 'game' took me only 10 minutes to complete, even with thoroughly reading and absorbing every detail.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps aside. It's an engaging way to challenge your mind while still being enjoyable. Although this game isn't as story-driven, it did give birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when I'm feeling bored, and I love to revisit what spawned a legend and what has become a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is relatively simple to explain. You utilize portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two types of buttons are in the game: one that you press and one that requires a cube to be placed on it.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally only encountered two: one minor and the other quite annoying) edit: both bugs are resolved - one fix increased my fps from 60-90 to 80-120 - and are looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews focus on specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€) Radeon RX480 (~200€) Z170 Pro Gaming (~150€) 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€) ~650€ is definitely within the medium price range, though granted, this rig is quite new. I consistently achieved 60+ fps on high settings with VSync enabled, which makes me question the 90% of comments claiming to have overkill setups yet only getting 20fps.

Remember Age of Mythology? It's been that long since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander reaches awfully close to the borders of my personal favorite RTS game. Combine this with a huge Risk-like grand strategy mode and it hits the spot. I try not to be overly biased, but the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, supporting, attacking, and commanding unit production, direction, and spawning at the same time, is a major draw. Honestly, I do like complicated RTS games nowadays, such as Civ V. However, such games often attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources into one complicated game mode, which can be overwhelming.

Undertale comes together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title, and the music is pleasant, but paired together they create truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script spans a wide range of emotions, from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, often simultaneously, and does this while subverting RPG tropes. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you enjoy RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your passing, play this game.

I've had this game for just a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, and their engagement is evident in the discussion forums and dev diaries. Although the game's mechanics have a fairly steep learning curve, which I'm still trying to master, this depth of strategy offers numerous ways to achieve goals and capitalize on certain situations. In my opinion, the game is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself fully immersed in every session, regardless of how the play-through unfolds.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the initial few hours of play. After this period, you'll begin to notice that the game's offerings are limited to repetitive combat, enemies, and gameplay. A significant high point is the developers' dedication to regular updates, which often include substantial content, such as system overhauls, new warframes, and various tweaks and features. It's suitable for casual play. However, I doubt it will sustain your interest beyond a few months unless you enjoy grinding. The game's free-to-play model is a significant advantage, making it worth trying out. If you're looking for a brief gaming experience, I recommend giving it a try.

This game is extremely dull. I purchased it, believing it to be a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it falls short. The gameplay involves absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb more. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels lack inventiveness, and the overall experience is a surreal, unsettling horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show, but one that leaves you feeling rather depressed and questioning the value of life. Every 'living' creature in the game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators had a fascination with taxidermy, given their lifeless and eerie portrayal.

Alright. Let me explain a few things, as someone very interested in politics, I was intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, 'oh wow, a simulator of the road to becoming president, that sounds fun!' Well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off and asks you to pick a side: Republican or Democrat, with no option for Independent or third-party affiliation. A little disappointed, but still optimistic, I continued to see what I could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is pretty enjoyable to experiment with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign – literally.

Fallout 3's story was superior. Settlements often hinder the narrative, making you feel like a babysitter rather than a player. Some keys are hardcoded and cannot be rebound. The game is plagued by bugs. At one point, my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, and I had to research console commands to retrieve it. Power armor is readily available from the start, and power cores are abundant in trader shops, greatly diminishing its value. The story is mediocre, and most aspects of the game are unremarkable, except for its stability, which surpasses Fallout 3's frequent crashes. However, it doesn't live up to the hype, and it's not better than Fallout 3 or New Vegas. This title's actual quality falls short of expectations.

My stats (at the time of writing this review): 
- 8.6 hours to complete the game 
- 10 collectibles found out of 25 
- zero achievements out of 15 

What I liked: 
- The visuals were impressive up until the last level (ice caves) 
- Although the story was not great, the ending (after the closing credits) somewhat redeemed my time spent playing this game 

What I disliked: 
- The visuals in the last level were uninteresting 
- The gameplay in the last level became significantly harder, making it a frustrating experience of repetition until I got it right 
- Achievements were overly challenging, with 13 out of 15 achieved by less than 2.1% of players.

Pros: +graphics. Cons: -bugs (notably environmental issues, such as getting stuck or encountering invisible walls despite clear line of sight) -excessive handholding and guidance -underwhelming AI -enemies often seem to have omniscient knowledge of the player's location upon detection -frustratingly high enemy accuracy, reminiscent of the first Ghost Warrior. -poorly implemented checkpoints and saving system. -unengaging storyline that fails to captivate. I wouldn't recommend this game unless it's heavily discounted (90% off), even then, playing it feels like a tedious chore, driven solely by the desire to complete it and move on to the next game in my library. Given the time wasted on the first Ghost Warrior, which was equally underwhelming and left me feeling relieved upon completion, I'm unlikely to see this game through to the end.

Review for 29/11/2015 - Avoid purchasing this game, as servers are offline, rendering it unplayable. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. During my brief time playing, I enjoyed the experience. As the Steve Miller Band song goes: "Go on take the money and run uh uh uhhh! Go on take the money and run..." https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 --- English - 73 minutes playing the game, and I must say, it's impressive! Just an hour in, and I'm hooked. Some guns are overpowered, and matchmaking can be unfair at times, but hey, Battlefield 3 had worse matchmaking issues. As a newbie, I was matched with higher-level players who seemed almost invincible - shooting them in the face had little effect.

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :d This puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large, intricate branching map. This game is quite amusing and running through it to complete the game was quite enjoyable. ^_^ However, it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements. To get all the cubes, you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher, which can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking into a guide (*raises hand* I gave up -_-). The guide, 'A Complete Guide to Fez!!!'

It's not hard for me to see why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't my cup of tea. As a Vive owner, I prefer playing room-sized games with controllers. Initially, the game's vast universe is awe-inspiring, but I found that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and time required to do anything interesting at the start were too steep for me. Perhaps with more patience and gaming time, this would be compelling. However, I don't have either luxury, and there are plenty of other VR games I'd rather spend my time on. The game's scale, while impressive, ultimately felt like a barrier.

Hands down, my all-time favorite first-person shooter. Run-and-gun enthusiasts need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are remarkably realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death, unless the shot merely grazes you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are necessary to remain on target. There is no infinite ammunition pool. If you frequently reload mid-magazine, you'll end up with a pouch full of partially used mags. Endless sprinting is not an option. After prolonged sprinting, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you've caught your breath. Resting your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill helps steady your aim. Accuracy is compromised when standing, but improves when using cover or a stable position.

I'll start by saying I didn't purchase EU when it first came out, instead buying it on sale, which included EW. As a result, I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had with that game. I loved it, though - it was unforgiving in the early stages, but rewarding when you executed things correctly. As for XCOM2, I'm a big fan; the game runs smoothly for me on medium settings, even with a GTX560 and 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game was set to high, and it ran a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable. However, when I dropped it down to medium, the performance improved significantly. I'm not sure if I'm just lucky when it comes to avoiding issues with games, but many of the negative reviews seem to be coming from people with unrealistic expectations.

+rpg levelling +wide-variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humored -grind intensive (if under utilizing the civvy station types) -sub-par ai teammates -limited equipment types -restricted levelling skills (no branching) This game is incredibly enjoyable. Despite the drawbacks, there's still variety and strategy to be found. The pace is fast from the start and only accelerates. Although equipment options are limited, there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. To extend the game's lifespan, mods are the way to go. Fight for Universe is the standout, but Big Fight for Beef is also noteworthy.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's growing economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the over 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued. Anti-globalisation campaigners have cancelled a demonstration planned for the weekend. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run concurrently with the WEF's more exclusive event in Davos.

Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal. Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. GM, whose European operations are struggling financially, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, following Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The US firm is thought to be offering approximately $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a competitive bid between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.

Cardinal criticises Iraq war, stating billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East could have been better utilised to alleviate poverty. Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor made these comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance in his Christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history by eradicating poverty".

British stars denied major Oscars. British hopes of winning major Oscars were dashed as UK stars failed to secure acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's Vera Drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards, and there was no prize for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost to Best Actress Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to win Best Supporting Actor awards. The UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film award for her gritty drama Wasp. Arnold, a former presenter of children's television shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, described the win as "totally overwhelming." Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Halloween writer Debra Hill dies. Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it grossed over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 1970s that were more commonly held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression as fast web access encourages more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of Britain's broadband users regularly upload content and maintain personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. Having an always-on, fast connection is transforming the way people use the internet. Over five million UK households have broadband, with this number growing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's internet habits. It found that more than half of broadband users logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse. More significantly, the report argues, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active online role.

Yukos heads back to US courts as Russian oil and gas company Yukos is set to appear in a US court on Thursday, continuing its fight for survival. The firm is being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. In an attempt to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas, Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, seeking to utilize international business law. However, the unit was sold to state oil firm Rosneft for $9.4bn, following a disrupted state auction. Yukos' lawyers now argue that the auction breached US bankruptcy law. The company and its primary shareholders have vowed to pursue any company that acquires its assets, employing all available legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site as voting gets underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed due to an overwhelming number of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and reports that more than 12,000 are added daily. According to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, a blog is created every 5.8 seconds, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing' - The China Three Gorges Project Corp is reportedly refusing to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, according to the Chinese state press. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, as stated by the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to stop due to inadequate environmental checks. The Beijing News suggests that the company may opt to pay a fine instead. The firm has also disregarded orders to cease construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges project electrical power supply plant. To date, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have adhered to the shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient, and they managed to fashion just one clear chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar, with their overall performance lacking the desired fluidity and precision.

Wales 'must learn health lessons' - the new health minister for Wales says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job after Jane Hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats argued that Dr Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms Hutt defended her record, stating that waiting times and lists comprised "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." One of the biggest problems Ms Hutt faced during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the lengthy waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve. Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' gritty performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with plenty of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed plenty of character and determination and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also hailed senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which few other players possess.

A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. 'A Different Story' will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, running from 10-20 February. The film features the singer discussing his career and personal life, from his Wham! days to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and Executive Producer Andy Stephens will also be in attendance. The 93-minute film sees Michael reflecting on his early Wham! days, as well as his later career, including his high-profile legal battles with Sony and his outspoken stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter US singles chart; digital music downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from music download sales, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's 'Boulevard of Broken Dreams' is currently number two in Billboard's Pop chart and tops its Digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. In the US, digital sales are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with physical singles sales and airplay information to make up the new Hot 100 chart. The second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales, but confines its airplay information to US radio stations playing chart music.

Anti-spam laws have taken a significant toll on the self-declared "spam king" of the net, who is now seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the mastermind behind Optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, stated that lawsuits have forced the company into Chapter 11. Optinrealbig was embroiled in several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company claims that filing for Chapter 11 will enable it to resolve its legal issues while continuing to operate. Ranked as the world's third biggest spammer by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, Optinrealbig was sued in December 2003 for sending mail messages that contravened anti-spam laws. The lawsuit, brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries, violating anti-spam regulations.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham's Sporting Director, Frank Arnesen, has denied that Coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "The sole reason for his resignation is his own personal problems." He recently spoke to me about this matter, stating it was entirely personal. Arnesen was unable to shed light on the problems that led to Santini's departure after just 13 games in charge. He added: "Jacques has never disclosed the exact nature of his issues. However, I trust him, and you have to accept it. I think we should respect his privacy.

Ireland surged past the Scots, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to hosting England at Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will attempt to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy visit Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

Economy focus for election battle: Britain's economic future will be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. Following the final cabinet meeting at No 10 before the expected election announcement, he asserted that voters would acknowledge Labour's role in bringing stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the Lib Dems provided more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury penned an open letter to all three parties, urging them not to exploit people's fears during the election. He called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime, instead.

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's championships in Sheffield. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not participate in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title at the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will aim to secure his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in outstanding form on the European circuit in recent weeks, establishing himself as one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter, and appears likely to secure a spot in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg at the European championships, with Carroll currently ranked third in the world 3000m rankings, while Cragg occupies the top spot.

Robinson eyes dual code success as England rugby union captain Jason Robinson targets a historic win over Australia on Saturday. A former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, Robinson leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. At 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the Tri-Nations tournament final. "Securing victories in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England can seal their third autumn international win after successive victories over Canada and South Africa, and gain revenge for June's 51-15 loss to the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of failure against Australia with a win at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Net users are advised to avoid a scam website claiming to collect funds on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears plausible, utilizing an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, DEC has no connection with the fake site and has reported it to the police. This site is the latest in a series of scams attempting to capitalize on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam email currently circulating, with a subject line reading "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and text featuring poor grammar and spelling characteristic of phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids. Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licences, aiming to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. The Ministry of Communications has invited bids from local, Arab, and foreign companies. The winning bidder will partner with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate" from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within 10 years. It also hopes to develop a "highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector". The bidding and tender process details will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. A road-show for investors is also planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to net security as older individuals and women increasingly take charge of protecting home computers against malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for net security firm Preventon, indicates that security messages are resonating with a diverse range of surfers. It is estimated that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retirees. Over the last three years, this figure has increased by an average of 13.2%. Notably, more retired women (53%) were purchasing security software than retired men. The research reflects shifting stereotypes and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the heightened risks associated with high-speed broadband internet connections.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, a considerable amount of space to fill. However, an increasing number of iPod owners are utilizing this space for audio content created by a diverse range of producers. This phenomenon is known as "podcasting," with former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry being its most prominent advocate. Although podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, it is not necessary to own one to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show that podcasters produce, often from the comfort of their own homes. The required equipment is minimal, consisting of a microphone, a PC, and editing software. Once created, the shows are uploaded to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them at no cost.

Andrea Levy, the Orange Prize winner, has seen her novel 'Small Island' win the Whitbread Novel of the Year award. She is now the favourite to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's 'The Line of Beauty'. Geraldine McCaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for 'Not the End of the World'. All category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will meet on 25 January to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win, following her London-based success.

Yukos seeks court action on sale. Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the relatively unknown firm that has acquired its main asset. Yukos has stated its intention to sue Baikal and other parties involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal's assets frozen after the Russian government disregarded a US court order last week blocking the sale. The background and motives of Baikal, which purchased the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) at a state-provoked auction on Sunday, remain unclear. Russian newspapers have alleged that Baikal has strong ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts 2-1 Livingston. Hearts sealed their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals within the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening minute, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, effectively putting the game beyond the visitors' reach. Craig Easton headed in a contentious goal after an hour, but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken had clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livingston box, and Miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, delivering a cross to the back post where McAllister timed his run to head past Meldrum.

Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service, offering processing by the hour. This service allows customers requiring substantial computing power to rent it on an hourly basis. The Sun Grid costs users $1 (53p) per hour for processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. Grid computing, the latest buzz phrase, is a concept where computing capacity is viewed as a commodity, comparable to hardware and software. Sun draws parallels between grid computing and the development of electricity. According to Sun's Chief Operating Officer, Jonathan Schwartz, the system could mature similarly to utilities like electricity and water. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California.

Jamieson issues warning to bigots. Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to take a tough stance by banning them from matches, hitting them "where it hurts most". Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are one of several measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the problem. However, the minister emphasized that stopping sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches remains a key objective. Ms Jamieson made the remarks ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week, Ms Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

UK debut for Kevin Spacey movie. Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, Beyond the Sea, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT The Tykes have signed Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, with Kevin Sorrell coming in at outside centre. - Friday's game at Headingley received the go-ahead on Friday after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future as the fixed line phone in your home may soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people are relying on their mobile phones for every call they make or receive. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use a mobile. It found that individuals retain their fixed line phones due to lower call charges, but most respondents believed the future of communication lies with mobile devices. The Nokia-sponsored research indicated that mobiles and fixed phones serve different purposes. Home phones are used for longer, more in-depth conversations, whereas mobile conversations tend to be shorter, often between friends. In the UK, 69% of those surveyed stated they opt for their fixed phone because it remains a more cost-effective option than a mobile.

A group of MPs has attempted to increase pressure on Tony Blair regarding reform of the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber, in which 70% of members would be elected. Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats, MPs and peers have failed to reach an agreement on reform. The group claims it can garner support for removing the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government postponed plans to remove these peers, citing low chances of success due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued that consensus is necessary for reforms. There have been suggestions that Labour's manifesto will include proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords.

Disappointed Scott makes solid start. Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a promising debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final, having won his heat in 7.64secs but running 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix Circuit final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it needs refilling, even when it still contains ink. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges utilize chip technology to detect when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. However, the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of their ink levels.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast. UK broadcaster Virgin Radio has announced that it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website, enabling the service. James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, stated, "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland added, "This application will enable anyone, anywhere, to listen to Virgin Radio simply by using the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music to Perform at Isle of Wight Festival. Roxy Music will join Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild at the Isle of Wight Music Festival in June. REM have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will perform on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is currently working on new material in the studio, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year, Roxy Music achieved their first hit with 1972's Virginia Plain. Other notable hits include Street Life, Love Is the Drug, and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's Jealous Guy.

Captains line up for aid match: Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is among four Six Nations captains selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami also join the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. This match will provide Woodward an opportunity to assess some options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, set to visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he added.

Sideways dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. The film was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, alongside writing partner Jim Taylor. Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen received acting awards for their performances. Sideways is expected to fare well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. Now in their 20th year, the awards honor films produced outside the traditional studio system and are typically held the day before the Oscars. Catalina Sandino Moreno took Best Actress for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama Maria Full of Grace. Moreno is also an Oscar nominee for Best Actress. Joshua Marston received the Best First Screenplay award for Maria Full of Grace, a film that also earned him a directing nomination.

Prince Crowned 'Top Music Earner'. Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, surpassing artists such as Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer banked $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album sales, and publishing royalties, thanks to his Musicology tour and album. He edged out Madonna, who earned $54.9m (£29.5m) while embarking on her global Re-Invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel secured 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (£13.4m) last year. "Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in commercial obscurity," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour generated $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

Irish band U2 received a special achievement prize at France's biggest music awards, but were beaten to the international group award by boy band Blue. U2 were honoured at the NRJ Music Awards, where US band Maroon 5 was named best new international artist and took the best international song title for 'This Love'. Over five million radio listeners voted in the awards. The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively. At the Cannes ceremony, U2 frontman Bono collected the award from model Naomi Campbell, saying in French: "I'm not from this country but I'll make a little confession to you - it's at the Cote d'Azur I feel at home." Blue's win came as a surprise, beating U2 to the top prize.

Wal-mart fights back at accusers as two big US names launch advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer, Wal-mart, took out over 100 full-page adverts in national newspapers to counter criticism. The group aims to address concerns over its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Wal-mart initiated the battle with adverts in prominent newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, featuring an open letter from company president Lee Scott, stating it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth". "There are many misconceptions circulating about Wal-mart, but facts are facts," he emphasized, seeking to dispel "urban legends" surrounding the company.

Tories have outlined policing plans, proposing that local communities elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard stated that the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He clarified that the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Lib Dems argued that the plan could allow extreme groups to control policing, while Labour criticized "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, Jan Berry, chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank and file officers, emphasized that retaining operational independence was essential. She said: "Policing is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned, echoing concerns about potential politicization.

At a glance: Tory health checks. The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: people moving to the UK from outside the EU to live and work. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with high TB rates, they would be required to undergo a chest x-ray and further tests if necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who want to stay a year or more will be required to undergo a comprehensive medical examination. This will include tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test result would automatically lead to visa applications being rejected. All other conditions would be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes - has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic encounter in Paris? Can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? These are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of the three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in". A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "there was a French half and a Welsh half, that's how it felt".

Doves soar to UK album summit; Manchester rock band Doves have entered the UK album chart at number one with their new release, Some Cities. The trio replace flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top. The album follows single Black and White Town, which reached number six. R&B star Nelly has the new number one single with Over and Over, a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, alongside Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, (Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame, entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's Wake Me Up. Akon's Locked Up is at number five, while Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with Oh My God, solidifying their rising status.

Davies favours Gloucester future, Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to remain with his current team. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is currently on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proven his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies without a contract, forcing him to take a semi-professional deal with Neath RFC. Although he gained match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he previously expressed frustration with the way he was treated before his move to Gloucester.

Cabinet anger at Brown's cash raid: ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans, but emphasized that local governments must deliver good services without significant council tax increases. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr Raynsford noted that nearly all central government departments have an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club looks to Africa for talent, with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab side to compete in European competition, will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Zimbabwe's national team goalkeeper, Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin defeat Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro recently moved to Israel after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club, based in Sakhnin near Haifa, won the Israeli Cup final last season and is a high-profile promoter of peace and co-operation within Israel, with a strong ethnic mix.

New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by reducing drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University College London research claims that lowering the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives annually. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs are due to vote on the government's Road Safety Bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, says that lowering the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads compared to 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m annually. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested such a move could save around 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm^2 diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512×512 μm^2. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline, thereby eliminating the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC, fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process, consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality was successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting, demonstrating its effectiveness.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to mitigate the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by saving on tolls, while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HDVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HDVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This capability has not only allowed for the manipulation of increasingly larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior but also sparked ideas for utilizing mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, as well as precision force sensors that operate beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to a broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals suggested overcoming this limitation by establishing strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems have been achieved, they have yet to access nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product evaluations to inform customer decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated by professional spammers using fake reviews, who continually adapt and refine their spamming strategies to evade detection. Capturing these strategies is challenging, as they can change rapidly over time, vary across spammers and target products, and often remain unknown. Moreover, existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which may not align with maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we propose a minimax game where spammers and spam detectors compete based on practical goals that extend beyond detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game yield stable detectors that are robust to various detection strategies, ensuring the reliability of product evaluations.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employed the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identified a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We defined a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses was found to be superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.
